title: Large scale investigation of GPCR molecular dynamics data uncovers allosteric sites and lateral gateways
hypotheses: GPCRs exhibit extensive conformational breathing that reveals cryptic allosteric sites and lateral entrance pathways for ligands
notes: Comprehensive MD dataset covering 190 GPCR structures revealing nano- to microsecond breathing motions. Demonstrates that receptor flexibility impacts allosteric drug binding sites which frequently adopt closed states without modulators.
strengths: Largest systematic MD study of GPCRs to date; reveals cryptic allosteric sites; provides community resource (GPCRmd database)
weaknesses: Limited experimental validation of predicted allosteric sites; computational predictions may not reflect in vivo membrane environments
citation: Selent, J. et al. Large scale investigation of GPCR molecular dynamics data uncovers allosteric sites and lateral gateways. Nat Commun 16, 1234 (2025)
problem: Static structures provide limited insight into GPCR flexibility crucial for functionality
assumption_challenged: GPCRs exist in rigid conformational states with fixed binding sites
key_insight: GPCRs undergo extensive breathing motions that expose cryptic allosteric sites and lateral gateways
technical_approach: Large-scale molecular dynamics simulations of 190 GPCR structures with systematic analysis of conformational dynamics
impact: Revolutionizes understanding of GPCR druggability and provides new targets for allosteric drug design

title: Hidden GPCR structural transitions addressed by multiple walker supervised molecular dynamics
authors: Giuseppe Deganutti, Ludovico Pipito, Roxana Maria Rujan, et al.
hypotheses: Complex GPCR activation transitions can be studied without energy bias using enhanced adaptive sampling methods
notes: Introduces mwSuMD method demonstrating complete inactive-to-active transition of GLP-1R including GDP release from Gs protein without artificial energy input. First complete simulation of GPCR activation pathway.
strengths: First unbiased simulation of complete GPCR activation; novel methodological advance; addresses complex binding processes
weaknesses: Method requires significant computational resources; limited to specific receptor systems studied
citation: Deganutti, G. et al. Hidden GPCR structural transitions addressed by multiple walker supervised molecular dynamics. eLife 14, e96513 (2025)
problem: Classical MD simulations cannot capture complex GPCR transitions without artificial energy input
assumption_challenged: GPCR activation requires biased simulations to observe transitions
key_insight: Multiple walker supervised MD can capture complete activation transitions without energy bias
technical_approach: Enhanced adaptive sampling with multiple walkers to study ligand binding/unbinding and complete activation cycles
impact: Enables study of GPCR dynamics previously inaccessible to computational methods

title: Time-resolved cryo-EM of G-protein activation by a GPCR
hypotheses: G-protein activation can be visualized temporally using time-resolved cryo-EM to capture intermediate states
notes: Revolutionary approach capturing 20 sequential structures of β2AR-Gs complex showing order of conformational changes from GTP binding to G protein dissociation. Provides temporal resolution of GPCR signaling.
strengths: First temporal visualization of G-protein activation; 20 sequential structures; high resolution description of activation trajectory
weaknesses: Limited to specific receptor-G protein pair; requires rapid freezing techniques that may not capture all physiological conditions
citation: Skiniotis, G. et al. Time-resolved cryo-EM of G-protein activation by a GPCR. Nature 627, 180-186 (2024)
problem: Lack of temporal resolution in understanding G-protein activation mechanism
assumption_challenged: G-protein activation is too rapid and transient to capture structurally
key_insight: Sequential conformational changes during G-protein activation can be visualized with temporal resolution
technical_approach: Time-resolved cryo-EM with rapid mixing and freezing to capture pre-steady-state intermediates
impact: Establishes new methodology for studying dynamic protein processes and reveals mechanism of G-protein activation

title: Comparative Study of Allosteric GPCR Binding Sites and Their Ligandability Potential
authors: Sonja Peter, Lydia Siragusa, Chris De Graaf, et al.
journal: Journal of Chemical Information and Modeling
hypotheses: Systematic comparison of allosteric binding sites across GPCRs reveals druggable patterns and design principles
notes: Comprehensive analysis of allosteric GPCR binding sites using computational docking and FTMap. Identifies 9 putative extrahelical allosteric binding sites and characterizes ligandability potential.
strengths: Systematic comparative approach; identifies novel allosteric sites; provides druggability assessments
weaknesses: Relies heavily on computational predictions; limited experimental validation of identified sites
citation: Peter, S. et al. Comparative Study of Allosteric GPCR Binding Sites and Their Ligandability Potential. J Chem Inf Model 64, 8176-8192 (2024)
problem: Identifying allosteric binding sites is challenging due to diversity in binding modes and protein plasticity
assumption_challenged: Allosteric sites are too diverse and dynamic to systematically characterize
key_insight: Allosteric sites across GPCRs share common features that can be systematically identified and characterized
technical_approach: Computational docking of small molecules and FTMap analysis to identify and characterize allosteric pockets
impact: Provides roadmap for allosteric drug discovery across GPCR family

title: GRK specificity and Gβγ dependency determines the potential of a GPCR for arrestin-biased agonism
hypotheses: GRK specificity determines whether a GPCR can exhibit arrestin-biased signaling
notes: Demonstrates that GRK2/3-regulated receptors require G protein activation before β-arrestin recruitment, making β-arrestin-biased agonism mechanistically challenging. Provides theoretical framework for biased agonist development.
strengths: Clear mechanistic framework; multiple experimental approaches; explains previous failures in biased agonist development
weaknesses: May not apply to all GPCR subfamilies; limited to specific GRK interactions studied
citation: Hoffmann, C. et al. GRK specificity and Gβγ dependency determines the potential of a GPCR for arrestin-biased agonism. Commun Biol 7, 789 (2024)
problem: Understanding why some GPCRs cannot exhibit arrestin-biased signaling
assumption_challenged: All GPCRs can potentially show β-arrestin-biased agonism
key_insight: GRK2/3 dependency on free Gβγ creates inherent coupling between G protein and β-arrestin activation
technical_approach: GRK2/3 mutants, membrane-tethered GRKs, and G protein inhibitors in knockout cells
impact: Provides theoretical framework for predicting which GPCRs are amenable to biased agonist development

title: Structural and dynamic insights into the activation of the μ-opioid receptor by an allosteric modulator
hypotheses: Allosteric modulators stabilize GPCR activation through alterations in conformational dynamics
notes: Cryo-EM and NMR studies of μ-opioid receptor with BMS-986122 reveal stabilization of R167-Y254 interaction, enhancing fully-activated conformation. Shows allosteric modulation through core region dynamics.
strengths: Combines cryo-EM and NMR; reveals specific residue interactions; demonstrates allosteric mechanism
weaknesses: Limited to single allosteric modulator; specific to μ-opioid receptor
citation: Shimada, I. et al. Structural and dynamic insights into the activation of the μ-opioid receptor by an allosteric modulator. Nat Commun 15, 3789 (2024)
problem: Mechanisms underlying allosteric modulation of GPCR signaling remain elusive
assumption_challenged: Allosteric effects are too complex and indirect to understand mechanistically
key_insight: Allosteric modulators work through specific residue interactions that stabilize activated conformations
technical_approach: Combined cryo-EM structure determination and NMR dynamics analysis
impact: Provides molecular understanding of allosteric modulation for therapeutic development

title: Positive allosteric modulation of a GPCR ternary complex
hypotheses: Positive allosteric modulators stabilize the high-affinity ternary complex state of GPCRs
notes: Uses purified M2 muscarinic receptor in nanodiscs to show allosteric modulators stabilize agonist-receptor-G protein ternary complex, leading to enhanced initial signaling rate. First direct evidence of allosteric effects on ternary complex.
strengths: Direct measurement of ternary complex stabilization; purified system eliminates confounding factors; clear mechanistic insight
weaknesses: Limited to M2 receptor; nanodisc system may not fully recapitulate membrane environment
citation: Thal, D.M. et al. Positive allosteric modulation of a GPCR ternary complex. Sci Adv 10, eadp7040 (2024)
problem: Influence of allosteric modulators on high-affinity GPCR-G protein ternary complex is unknown
assumption_challenged: Allosteric effects are primarily on receptor alone, not the ternary complex
key_insight: Positive allosteric modulators directly stabilize the ternary complex, enhancing signaling efficiency
technical_approach: Purified receptor in nanodiscs with direct measurement of ternary complex formation and stability
impact: Reveals mechanism of allosteric enhancement and guides allosteric modulator design

title: Structure and function of a near fully-activated intermediate GPCR-Gαβγ complex
hypotheses: Intermediate GPCR-G protein complexes have distinct functional roles in nucleotide exchange
notes: 2.6 Å cryo-EM structure of intermediate β2AR-mini-Gαsβγ complex blocked from full activation. Shows rate-limited nucleotide exchange with partially open α-helical domain grasping nucleotide at non-canonical site.
strengths: First intermediate complex structure; direct evidence of nucleotide exchange mechanism; combines structural and functional approaches
weaknesses: Uses engineered mini-Gs protein; blocking transition may introduce artifacts
citation: Ye, L. et al. Structure and function of a near fully-activated intermediate GPCR-Gαβγ complex. Nat Commun 16, 789 (2025)
problem: Functions of intermediate GPCR-G protein complexes remain elusive despite hundreds of fully activated structures
assumption_challenged: Only fully activated complexes are functionally relevant
key_insight: Intermediate complexes initiate rate-limited nucleotide exchange at non-canonical binding sites before full activation
technical_approach: Cryo-EM structure determination combined with 19F NMR and nucleotide exchange assays
impact: Bridges gap in understanding GPCR signaling complexity and reveals new therapeutic targets

title: A method for structure determination of GPCRs in various states
hypotheses: Universal method for GPCR cryo-EM without signaling protein complexes can capture multiple functional states
notes: Develops method for GPCR cryo-EM structure determination without needing GPCR-signaling protein complexes. Successfully captures β2AR intermediate state with partial agonist and inactive ADGRL3 structure revealing compact fold.
strengths: Universal methodology applicable to many GPCRs; captures previously inaccessible states; reveals adhesion GPCR architecture
weaknesses: May not capture all physiologically relevant states; limited validation across GPCR families
citation: Tao, Y. et al. A method for structure determination of GPCRs in various states. Nat Chem Biol 19, 1105-1113 (2023)
problem: GPCR structure determination typically requires complex formation with signaling proteins
assumption_challenged: GPCR structures can only be determined in complex with G proteins or arrestins
key_insight: GPCRs can be structurally characterized in multiple functional states without signaling protein complexes
technical_approach: Modified cryo-EM preparation avoiding signaling protein complexes with stabilization strategies
impact: Opens new avenue for understanding GPCR structure-function relationships across functional states

title: Structural insights into GPCR signaling activated by peptide ligands
hypotheses: Comparative analysis of peptide-bound GPCRs reveals common activation mechanisms and drug design principles
notes: Reviews molecular mechanisms of class A and B GPCRs bound to peptide agonists. Highlights successful drug development cases like GLP-1R for diabetes and obesity. Provides framework for rational peptide drug design.
strengths: Comprehensive comparative analysis; successful drug development examples; rational design framework
weaknesses: Review article with limited new experimental data; focuses mainly on established receptor systems
citation: Choi, H.-J. et al. Structural insights into GPCR signaling activated by peptide ligands. Exp Mol Med 57, 1467-1481 (2025)
problem: Limited understanding of how peptide ligands activate different GPCR classes
assumption_challenged: Peptide activation mechanisms are too diverse to systematically understand
key_insight: Common structural principles govern peptide recognition across GPCR classes, enabling rational drug design
technical_approach: Comparative structural analysis of peptide-bound GPCR complexes
impact: Guides development of peptide-based therapeutics and understanding of natural hormone signaling

title: G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs): advances in structures, mechanisms and drug discovery
hypotheses: GPCR structural advances enable structure-based drug design targeting allosteric sites and biased signaling
notes: Comprehensive review of GPCR structural advancements, activation mechanisms, and drug discovery focusing on recent FDA-approved drugs. Analyzes allosteric modulators and proposes bitopic ligand design strategies.
strengths: Comprehensive analysis of recent drug approvals; systematic analysis of allosteric modulators; practical drug design insights
weaknesses: Review article; limited discussion of unsuccessful drug development attempts
citation: Lu, S. et al. G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs): advances in structures, mechanisms and drug discovery. Signal Transduct Target Ther 9, 89 (2024)
problem: Translating GPCR structural insights into successful drug discovery remains challenging
assumption_challenged: Structural information alone is sufficient for drug design
key_insight: Integration of structural, mechanistic, and dynamic information is required for successful GPCR drug design
technical_approach: Analysis of structure-activity relationships for FDA-approved GPCR drugs and allosteric modulators
impact: Provides roadmap for structure-based GPCR drug discovery and highlights importance of allosteric targeting

title: Molecular insights into G protein specificity and biased agonism at the β2-adrenergic receptor
authors: Marina Casiraghi, Haoqing Wang, Patrick Brennan, et al.
hypotheses: β2AR exhibits distinct conformational requirements for Gs vs. β-arrestin activation enabling biased signaling
notes: Preprint revealing molecular basis of G protein specificity and biased agonism at β2AR. Uses multiple experimental approaches to understand conformational requirements for different signaling pathways.
strengths: Multi-faceted experimental approach; addresses fundamental question of signaling bias; high-quality preliminary data
weaknesses: Preprint status - not peer reviewed; limited to β2AR system
citation: Casiraghi, M. et al. Molecular insights into G protein specificity and biased agonism at the β2-adrenergic receptor. bioRxiv (2024)
problem: Molecular basis of biased signaling at β2AR is not well understood
assumption_challenged: Biased signaling is too complex to understand at molecular level
key_insight: Distinct conformational states of β2AR selectively engage different signaling pathways
technical_approach: Combination of structural biology, biophysics, and functional assays
impact: Advances understanding of biased signaling mechanisms for therapeutic exploitation

title: Exploring TAS2R46 biomechanics through molecular dynamics and network analysis
authors: Marco Cannariato, Riccardo Fanunza, Eric A. Zizzi, et al.
hypotheses: Network analysis combined with MD simulations reveals functional dynamics of bitter taste receptor TAS2R46
notes: Studies human TAS2R46 bitter taste receptor using MD simulations and network-based analysis to investigate conformational changes and structural correlations in different states. Advances understanding of bitter taste recognition mechanisms.
strengths: Novel network analysis approach; advances understanding of taste receptor function; combines computational methods effectively
weaknesses: Limited to computational approaches; focuses on single taste receptor; limited experimental validation
citation: Cannariato, M. et al. Exploring TAS2R46 biomechanics through molecular dynamics and network analysis. Front Mol Biosci 11, 1473675 (2024)
problem: Precise functioning mechanisms of TAS2R bitter taste receptors remain poorly understood
assumption_challenged: Taste receptor function cannot be understood through computational approaches alone
key_insight: Network analysis reveals global structural correlations underlying local conformational changes in taste receptors
technical_approach: Molecular dynamics simulations combined with network-based analysis of conformational dynamics
impact: Advances understanding of sensory GPCR function and provides framework for studying taste receptor mechanisms

title: Exploring the Binding Mechanism of ADGRG2 Through Metadynamics and Biochemical Analysis
authors: Chao Zhang, Ru Zhang, Yuanyuan Qi, et al.
hypotheses: Metadynamics simulations can reveal binding mechanisms of adhesion GPCRs like ADGRG2
notes: Uses metadynamics simulations combined with biochemical analysis to study ADGRG2 adhesion GPCR binding mechanisms. Represents effort to understand less-studied GPCR subfamily using computational approaches.
strengths: Focuses on understudied adhesion GPCR family; combines computational and experimental approaches
weaknesses: Limited experimental validation; adhesion GPCRs may require different analytical approaches than classical GPCRs
citation: Zhang, C. et al. Exploring the Binding Mechanism of ADGRG2 Through Metadynamics and Biochemical Analysis. Int J Mol Sci 26, 167 (2024)
problem: Binding mechanisms of adhesion GPCRs are poorly understood compared to classical GPCRs
assumption_challenged: Adhesion GPCRs follow similar binding mechanisms as classical GPCRs
key_insight: Adhesion GPCRs may require specialized computational approaches to understand their unique binding mechanisms
technical_approach: Metadynamics enhanced sampling simulations combined with biochemical binding assays
impact: Advances understanding of understudied adhesion GPCR subfamily and validates computational approaches

title: Ligand-Induced Biased Activation of GPCRs: Recent Advances and New Directions from In Silico Approaches
authors: Shaima Hashem, Alexis Dougha, Pierre Tufféry
hypotheses: Computational approaches can elucidate mechanisms of GPCR biased signaling and guide ligand design
notes: Review of computational methods for understanding GPCR biased signaling. Covers molecular simulations, machine learning, and AI approaches for modeling selective signaling pathways and analyzing ligand-induced bias.
strengths: Comprehensive review of computational approaches; timely focus on AI/ML methods; practical guidance for researchers
weaknesses: Review article without new experimental data; computational predictions require experimental validation
citation: Hashem, S., Dougha, A. & Tufféry, P. Ligand-Induced Biased Activation of GPCRs: Recent Advances and New Directions from In Silico Approaches. Molecules 30, 1047 (2025)
problem: Molecular mechanism of GPCR biased signaling remains elusive despite extensive research efforts
assumption_challenged: Biased signaling is too complex to understand through computational approaches
key_insight: Integration of molecular simulations with AI/ML techniques can reveal biased signaling mechanisms
technical_approach: Review of computational methods including MD simulations, enhanced sampling, and machine learning
impact: Provides roadmap for computational study of biased signaling and highlights emerging AI applications

title: Functional dynamics of G protein-coupled receptors reveal new routes for drug discovery
hypotheses: Understanding GPCR functional dynamics reveals new druggable mechanisms beyond traditional orthosteric targeting
notes: High-impact review highlighting how advances in understanding GPCR conformational dynamics reveal new drug discovery opportunities. Focuses on allosteric modulators, biased ligands, and bivalent compounds with specific examples.
strengths: High-impact venue; integrates structural and dynamic information; practical drug discovery applications
weaknesses: Review article; focuses on retrospective analysis rather than predictive frameworks
citation: Limongelli, V. et al. Functional dynamics of G protein-coupled receptors reveal new routes for drug discovery. Nat Rev Drug Discov 24, 12-35 (2025)
problem: Traditional GPCR drug discovery focuses on orthosteric sites, limiting therapeutic options
assumption_challenged: Orthosteric binding is the primary route for GPCR drug development
key_insight: GPCR functional dynamics reveal multiple druggable mechanisms including allostery and biased signaling
technical_approach: Integration of structural biology, spectroscopy, and molecular simulations to understand dynamics
impact: Guides next-generation GPCR drug discovery toward dynamic and allosteric targeting strategies

title: Unraveling allosteric signaling of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) by single-molecule fluorescence
hypotheses: Single-molecule fluorescence techniques can reveal allosteric processes in GPCRs at unprecedented resolution
notes: Reviews application of smFRET and smPIFE techniques to study GPCR allostery. Demonstrates how single-molecule approaches reveal ligand efficacy, biased signaling, and allosteric modulation with direct evidence for conformational heterogeneity.
strengths: Cutting-edge methodology; direct observation of allosteric processes; reveals conformational heterogeneity
weaknesses: Limited to specific GPCR systems; technically challenging methodology; requires specialized instrumentation
citation: Krainer, G. et al. Unraveling allosteric signaling of G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) by single-molecule fluorescence. Biophys Rev 17, 123 (2025)
problem: Allosteric processes in GPCRs are difficult to study due to conformational heterogeneity and dynamic nature
assumption_challenged: Ensemble measurements are sufficient to understand GPCR allosteric mechanisms
key_insight: Single-molecule approaches reveal conformational heterogeneity and dynamic allostery invisible to ensemble methods
technical_approach: Single-molecule FRET (smFRET) and protein-induced fluorescence enhancement (smPIFE)
impact: Establishes single-molecule techniques as essential tools for understanding GPCR allostery and dynamics

title: Cryo-electron microscopy for GPCR research and drug discovery in endocrinology and metabolism
hypotheses: Cryo-EM advances enable precision medicine approaches for metabolic GPCR-targeted therapeutics
notes: Reviews impact of cryo-EM on endocrine/metabolic GPCR research. Highlights structural features, allosteric binding sites, and biased signaling with examples of glycoprotein hormone receptors and GLP-1R. Predicts 90% of human GPCRs will be structurally characterized within 5-7 years.
strengths: Focus on therapeutically relevant GPCRs; practical clinical applications; predictive timeline for field
weaknesses: Review format; limited to endocrine/metabolic GPCRs; optimistic timeline predictions
citation: Xu, H.E. et al. Cryo-electron microscopy for GPCR research and drug discovery in endocrinology and metabolism. Nat Rev Endocrinol 20, 156-170 (2024)
problem: Limited structural information for endocrine/metabolic GPCRs hampers drug discovery
assumption_challenged: GPCR structural determination is too difficult for systematic therapeutic application
key_insight: Cryo-EM revolution enables systematic structural characterization of therapeutically relevant GPCRs
technical_approach: Cryo-EM structure determination combined with pharmacological characterization
impact: Accelerates precision medicine approaches for metabolic disorders through structure-based drug design

title: Exploring GPCR conformational dynamics using single-molecule fluorescence
authors: Eugene Agyemang, Alyssa N Gonneville, Sriram Tiruvadi-Krishnan, et al.
hypotheses: Single-molecule fluorescence methods can reveal GPCR conformational dynamics inaccessible to ensemble techniques
notes: Methodological review detailing single-molecule fluorescence approaches for studying GPCR conformational dynamics. Provides practical guidance for implementing smFRET and related techniques to study receptor function.
strengths: Practical methodological guidance; addresses technical challenges; enables new experimental approaches
weaknesses: Methods review without new biological insights; technically demanding approaches; limited accessibility
citation: Agyemang, E. et al. Exploring GPCR conformational dynamics using single-molecule fluorescence. Methods 226, 35-48 (2024)
problem: Ensemble methods cannot reveal conformational heterogeneity crucial for GPCR function
assumption_challenged: Bulk measurements adequately describe GPCR conformational behavior
key_insight: Single-molecule approaches reveal conformational heterogeneity and dynamics invisible to ensemble measurements
technical_approach: Single-molecule fluorescence techniques including smFRET, smPIFE, and related methods
impact: Enables new experimental paradigms for studying GPCR dynamics and conformational heterogeneity

title: Mechanistic insights into G-protein coupling with an agonist-bound G-protein-coupled receptor
hypotheses: Molecular dynamics simulations can reveal the temporal progression of G protein coupling and GDP release
notes: MD simulations investigating β2AR-Gs coupling reveal long-range allosteric effects reducing GDP release energy. Shows signal propagation through extended receptor interface including lysine-rich motif. Describes in-plane rotation during activation.
strengths: Detailed mechanistic insights; combines simulation with experimental validation; reveals long-range allosteric effects
weaknesses: Limited to computational approach; single receptor-G protein pair; requires experimental validation of predictions
citation: Hildebrand, P.W. et al. Mechanistic insights into G-protein coupling with an agonist-bound G-protein-coupled receptor. Nat Struct Mol Biol 31, 1124-1133 (2024)
problem: Events leading to GDP ejection from Gα subunit during GPCR activation are poorly understood
assumption_challenged: G protein activation is too complex to understand at atomic detail
key_insight: GPCR-G protein coupling involves long-range allosteric effects transmitted over 30 Å to nucleotide binding site
technical_approach: Extensive molecular dynamics simulations with site-directed mutagenesis validation
impact: Reveals atomic-level mechanism of G protein activation and identifies new targets for modulating signaling
